comments.commentBody:
There is one thing no one can dispute. We all heard it. During his "campaign" The Con Don called on Russia to hack and release Ms. Hillary Rodham Clinton's e-mails - and they did. He trumpeted out he and Russia's plans ahead of time, as did his buddies. They think WE do not care.

The idea that anyone - any true American - believes or supports him/them is so astonishing it is simply beyond comprehension.

The idea that this boy-child-ego-maniac would be allowed to continue to pretend to be some "elected leader", along with his hate-christian-radio-jock pretend vice president and the BIG democracy-destroying money master boy/girl operatives who think they "won", is equally astonishing.

WE must get them OUT of OUR governments at every level RIGHT NOW - before they can put their destructive global democracy-busting plans into effect. WE must DEMAND a new election with full participation because this was not one. WE had a Top 1% Global Financial Elite Robber Baron/ Radical Religion Good Old Boys' Party/ Cabal Financial Coup against OUR government and only WE can DEMAND it's full social/economic justice restoration.

NOW is the time. Every person in America who wants true democracy must pick one thing they value most and fight like hell to save it. Resist. Obstruct. Protest. Protect your neighbors and co-workers and let the public know when your rights are being trampled. Together WE can save the America WE love.

Regrettably, the Republican party has stood, for some time now, for nothing other than greed and corruption.  The Trump era has added a third quality to this list: treason.  Greed. corruption, and treason are fine by Paul Ryan, as long as he can continue his life as a leech on the government, cut taxes on the top .01%, and cut benefits on the middle and lower classes.  Same with Mitch McConnell.

You are so correct about this. It isn't the contact these people had with Russian officials, it is the denial of contact. But the new information about possible FISA approved wiretapping (don't know if this has been verified yet but was on BBC because President Trump went all twitteraholic about it) muddies the water.
But in the end it isn't the crime, it is the cover up that will get you.

Yes, Scott, let's stand strong with President Trump and his unhinged leadership.  You saw his tweets this AM, Scott?  I mean, you DID see them, didn't you?  So you want to stand tall with this guy? You are just part of the insanity.

Taking it to the really next level: Why remain a State? Independence for every State! Then this governor could be president.

Oops! Look at his favorability. Underwater! According to the Marquette U poll last November.

Pitiful ploy from a governor, who keeps repeating lies that he had death threats.

it's very good of the NY Times to print this. it would be better, much better journalism if this was accompanied by::

1) fact-checking of the major assertions made by the author of this piece. in today's world, fact-checking is more needed than ever because of fake news and continual propagandizing of information.

2) report on the number of this type of opposite opinion article published by avowedly right-wing media.

it's interesting that this article states that the centerpiece of the Republican agenda is to return authority to the states. this is debatable on two levels:

1) is this a good idea?
2) is this really want the Republican agenda is about?

in response to #1, we would be speaking Russian now if we had not had a strong central government. States Rights has been a slogan for regressive and repressive forces in this country for a long time. Try reading the Federalist Papers some time to see why the US failed under the Articles of Confederation, which created a weak central government with the states as almost sovereign nations.

in response to #2, the Republican party has been very, very successful with deceitful, evasive smoke screens about the true intentions of their programs.

IF THE STATES -- all 50-- had been DOING THEIR JOBS --- there would have been no need for Obamacare.

In every case where the federal government is involved, it is because states left citizens unserved and in need.

Quality of education, public safety, access to health coverage varied widely from state to state. All you have to do is look at infant mortality rates and graduation rates and quality of life measures and it is crystal clear that many states simply ignored citizen needs.

If all states had ensured that those in need could purchase coverage -- with financial help when needed -- Obama could have gone on to another issue. But Obama inherited the mess of people sickening and dying within cities where superb healthcare was available. THE STATES LET THAT HAPPEN.

So sorry, Loser Presidential candidate Scott, we cannot send vulnerable citizens back to the whims of state "leaders" who ignore their needs, who can barely manage their state budgets and who, when given block grants (I e handouts) for things like Medicaid are likely to spend it on roads or athletic stadiums.

Gov. Walker's assertion that the core GOP goal is returning power to the states is laughably false, nothing more than another recycling of the party's moldiest and most disreputable dog whistle. The GOP wants to roll back the expansion of health coverage on behalf of the for-profit medical complex, not the states, whose main function in health care delivery is to serve as a conduit for federal funds. The party has opposed every proposal that would reduce the profit margins of their corporate donor base, including drug companies and associations of wealthy doctors. That, not some fake concern about doctor choice or death panel nonsense, is their sole focus in all policy decisions regarding health care. Republicans are very consistent in putting donor class interest above public interest in every policy debate. Nothing to lower the profits of the gun industry, no matter how many Americans get shot down. Nothing to restrain the efforts of corporations to tap new veins of public funding for the incarceration industry, and, now with much salivating on the part of hedge fund charter school investors, the education sector. Full-on efforts to repeal regulations to protect the environment and protect citizens from financial industry predations in all its forms. I hope to see a day when the nonwealthy people who have given their allegiance to the GOP for generations, largely because of the party's skillful use of racial and cultural red herrings, come to see the party for what it is.
He just wants to point out that he weathered protests. He's like Guiliani's 9/11 and a verb. What's next? Your lunch? The motorcycle?

This man is my governor, and let there be no mistake--he has not stood strong against protesters (me included) for the people of Wisconsin. His people don't even live in Wisconsin; they're the ultra-rich plutocrats who put him in office and keep him there.
100,000 out of how many millions?

I was a resident and taxpayer of Wisconsin during Walker's years.  In practical terms his method was to reward friends and punish the opposition.  The rest of the state just paid the price; hundreds of millions of higher costs for Health Care, and loss of revenue because of tax breaks for select groups.  Teachers took a big compensation cut, and the environmental regulations are now set by industry.  Like Trump, Walker assigns blame to make unpopular ideas acceptable to his followers.
Put-up or shut-up time? Given how many craven Republicans have been ducking their constituents and refusing to hold town halls, it's not even show-up time.

Reading the title, I thought this was satire.
But never underestimate the ability of Republicans to stand truth on its head.
Walker is probably angling for a slot in the sinking ship at the White House.

How about air and water quality, Richard?  How about infrastructure? How about civil rights?  Turn it over to the states? Or are they interstate issues, matters that cross state lines or are important to the relationship of the individual to the federal government? Didn't we have a Civil War over that last category?

In Kansas we see the ideological replace reality as Governor Brownback steals from the highway fund and KPERS, the state employee retirement fund, to meet severe tax shortfalls and failed budgetary planning now under intense scrutiny from the State Legislature that will no longer tolerate the political ambitions of a Governor with his eyes on the White House as does Scott Walker. Their ideology provides cover for their presidential ambitions. Walker-Brownback are interchangeable arrogant men who care about their National aspirations not about the citizens who have suffered their absurd policy choices. Blind ambition is a poison that obscures reality. You sir, with your arrogance should join Sam Brownback on a trip to Mars where you can pursue those dreams that for the rest of us are but a nightmare without end.

Walker is good at demonizing protestors. Wisconsin residents (including teachers) know this all too well. Recall the prank phone call in 2011 he took during the height of the demonstrations in Madison when he mistook the caller for David Koch and he spelled out his true intentions, including the idea of planting people in the crowds outside the State Capitol Building as "troublemakers."

He is a thorn in the side of democracy in Wisconsin. That said the rest of the country might want to pay closer attention to the Badger state and what happens when far-right wing ideology controls all branches of government for that blueprint is now going national.

The rest of the country might learn other lessons from Wisconsin. In early 2011 Wisconsin inspired the world when thousands occupied the State Capital Building for two weeks. We marched in the hundreds of thousands, but these efforts fell short. We might consider the outcome had workers gone on strike and not put the fate of the movement into electoral politics and the failed recall vote of Walker that was dominated by outside money.

We might take a lesson from the massive immigrant rights demonstration that took place at the State Capitol Building in Madison on February 18, 2016 - The Day Without Latinos - when workers shut down the dairy industry across the state in response to two anti-immigrant bills. Funny how Walker forgot to mention that in his op ed. The reason: It was a moment when people power defeated his agenda.

It is hard to believe that once upon a time Wisconsin was the shining star of reform.  Rpbert  LaFolette led the nation in getting political corruption out of politics in his state. Scott Walker has been bought and paid for by the Koch brothers from the get go.  He has lied, manipulated and used every trick to destroy the benefits that worker in his state earned and deserve. He has used every political maneuver available to prevent any investigations into his dealings. He is the very epitome of the selfish, hypocritical  ideology of today's Republican Party. Guns for all, but not healthcare

• Explain that the centerpiece in the Republican agenda — returning authority to the states ....

“It is the first responsibility of every citizen to question authority.”
― BENJAMIN FRANKLIN

That "authority" must be returned to 'The People', where it lies, and who voted overwhelmingly, by around 2.8 million*, for Clinton. In a democracy it's the People's right and duty to protest and demand.

"But we should be outraged at what's going on in the world. Anger is not negative. Why shouldn't I be outraged? Why shouldn't I be bitter and angry?"
~ JULIE NICHOLSON, English vicar whose daughter, Jenny, died in the London tube bombings of July 2005.

* Do note that i saw it as MY duty to not vote for one of two scoundrels and abstained. It was my 'sacrifice' since I will have ceased to be a US citizen by the next presidential election and without regret will not qualify to vote.
So what you're saying is that New Yorkers can't govern themselves because corruption is endemic in your society? Pretty pathetic.

Mr. Walker, your alternate reality may not be as deranged as Mr. Trump's, but it's no less false.  You and your party leaders in the legislature have driven a fine, prosperous, progressive state straight down to the bottom - the bottom of almost every quality-of-life ranking among the 50 states.  Gloating about the incalculable damage you've done only confirms our worst thoughts about you.

It is increasingly evident that we are living with a criminal administration whose members' principal purpose is to protect their own power. The rank hypocrisy compared to their behavior during the Obama administration has now become so routine that the public ignores it. But the illegality that is yet before us is the most worrisome in our entire national history.

Sessions is the enabler. Lying, cheating, polluting, discrimination--all currently illegal--are now easily managed by passing legislation legalizing them. What can't be managed in law will be managed by simply not prosecuting this behavior. The public can try the courts, but this will be a frustrating exercise when the DOJ frustrates every effort to enforce the rule of law.

And it is deeply ironic that Sessions, who as AG is the enforcer of the rule of law seems to have no intention to do that--starting with his own behavior.

Yes, Virginia, it's hard to imagine - and extremely frightening - that The United States of America has a presidential pretender at the helm who mirrors the "child leader" of North Korea but that is the "reality" of it.

Vladimir Putin was elected president of Russia by an overwhelming majority of the Russian people. In other words, he is the president of the Russian people - their choice. He has not engaged in any pogroms or any activities usually associated with dictators. Further, Russia is an ally of the United States. It wasn't during the Cold War, but it is now. Russia is no threat to the United States. They are not a Caliphate seeking to rule the world. They have not threatened war against us, beheaded any of our citizens, or gunned down innocent Americans in California or Florida.

Finally, all this stuff about Putin and alleged hacking of Mrs. Clinton's e-mails to "steer" the election is nothing more than a continuation of pre-election partisan hype. There is no proof of it at all, and there is nothing sinister about any American who might talk to a Russian. And it's kind of funny for some so-called "Progressives," who regularly claim to only deal in facts to now accept innuendo, suspecions, and allegations as the basis of this continuing smear campaign against President Trump and President Putin.
Sorry, comrade, but Russia is not our ally.
